section.title: Overview
section.p: The NCC allows you to write rules and message filters to manipulate the generic processing of DiameterRequest and DiameterAnswer messages.

The following table describes actions available for DiameterRequest and DiameterAnswer contexts. See for an example of a Diameter Rule that manipulates generic processing of a DiameterRequest message. DiameterRequest and DiameterAnswer actions
Action
Description
Add-Metrics-Attribute Allows you to add metric attributes
Auth-Application-Id.Add Adds the Auth-Application-Id AVP in the message
Auth-Application-Id.Append Appends to the value of Auth-Application-Id AVP in the message
Auth-Application-Id.M-Bit Sets the Auth-Application-Id M-Bit in the message
Auth-Application-Id.P-Bit Sets the Auth-Application-Id P-Bit in the message
Auth-Application-Id..Prepend Prepends to the value of the Auth-Application-Id AVP in the message

Clear-Read-Indices
Allows you to clear the Read-Index cache maintained by the NCC. The cache is automatically cleared for public rule table invocations.
The action uses the following syntax:
<Context>.Clear-Read-Indices
The <context> can be any NCC message context. For example, GxCCA.Clear-Read-Indices will clear the Read-Index cache for the GxCCA message.
Clear-Routing-Peer An action used to clear the peer from the message.
Clear-Write-Indices
Allows you to clear the Write-Index cache maintained by the NCC. The cache is automatically cleared for public rule table invocations.
The action uses the following syntax:
<Context>.Clear-Write-Indices
The <context> can be any NCC message context. For example, GxCCA.Clear-Write-Indices will clear the Write-Index cache for the GxCCA message.
Delay When invoked from the Diameter Request/Answer filter, this action causes the routing of/replying to the message to be delayed by the specified duration in milliseconds. A duration less than 1 or greater than the maximum allowed delay results in the message not being delayed at all.

Discard When invoked from a request message filter, this action causes the message to be discarded without processing. The request is neither forwarded nor answered. For example, this action allows you to write filters to handle cases where the NCC is required to remain silent and not respond to any request messages.
Discard-Delayed-Messages When invoked from the Diameter Request, Diameter Answer, and Diameter Message rule sets, the Discard-Delayed-Messages attribute discards any delayed messages (for example, through the Delay rule attribute) that have the same Session-Id as the current message being processed.
Discard-With-Percentage When invoked from the Diameter Request, Diameter Answer, and Diameter Message rule sets, the Discard-Delayed-Messages-with-Percentage attribute discards any delayed messages along with the percentage of processed parts of the message in the current message being processed.
Log-EDR When invoked from the Diameter Request, Diameter Answer, and Diameter Message rule sets, this attribute enables EDR logging.

Route-To-Chosen-Peer The Route-To-Chosen-Peer action indicates that the diameter message should be routed to the chosen-peer that was stored in the message. When this action is used, the message will bypass the normal host and realm routing mechanisms.

Set-Application
This action allows you to change the application id of the message to the value specified. The value of the new Application-Id must be zero or greater.
Changing the Diameter Application-Id and/or the command-Number information can potentially make the content of a message invalid to another device. Nokia recommends that you contact Technical Support if you need to use these actions.
Set-Command This action allows you to change the command number of the Diameter message to the value specified. The new Command-Number must be zero or greater. This action should be used with caution as changing the command number can potentially make the content of a message invalid to another device.
Set-Long-Property The annotated action name for setting a long property in the message.
Set-Proxy-Flag Sets the P flag. If set, the message may be proxied, relayed, or redirected. If cleared, the message must be locally processed.
Set-Retransmission-Flag Sets the T flag. This flag is set after a link failover procedure, to aid the removal of duplicate requests. It is set when resending requests not yet acknowledged, as an indication of a possible duplicate due to a link failure. This bit MUST be cleared when sending a request for the first time, otherwise the sender MUST set this flag. Diameter agents only need to be concerned about the number of requests they send based on a single received request; retransmissions by other entities need not be tracked. Diameter agents that receive a request with the T flag set, MUST keep the T flag set in the forwarded request. This flag must not be set if an error answer message (protocol error) has been received for the earlier message. It can be set only in cases where no answer has been received from the server for a request and the request is sent again. This flag must not be set in answer messages.
Set-String-Property The annotated action name for setting a string property in the message.

Suppress-Route-Record Used to suppress the route-record AVP. The value for this property is a comma-separated list of the origin-host (for example, Diameter identity) of the gateways that do not support the route-record AVP. When a request or response is sent to any of these gateways, the route-record AVP will not be included in the message. Suppressing the route-record AVP is particularly important when the Diameter client is a Cisco node.

p.b: Example of manipulating the generic processing of a DiameterRequest messages

sectiondiv.p: For example, the NCC default validation of destination realm on incoming requests allows an incorrect realm to be processed. It ignores the destination realm if the wrong destination realm is received. If you want a more strict validation with error treatment, you can author Diameter rules to apply a stricter validation that returns the error code and vendor ID. The following is an example of how to configure a rule to protect the system from messages being sent to an 'unknown' destination host and/or realm. In the Message validation GUI, give the filter a name, a group-name, and optionally a description and Security Domain, then add the criterion and actions as follows:
